--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> This isn't specific to NEAT, but I found this article on the flaws 
of various AI approaches interesting:
> 
> http://www.generation5.org/content/2003/Why_AI_is_hard.asp
> It's at Generation 5, a Slashdot-type site dedicated to articles 
dealing with AI.
> 
> Anyway, I agree with the author that much of AI research is 
fundamentally conceptually flawed, and that these flaws often stem 
from an oversimplification of the meaning of "intelligence" 
and/or "intelligent behavior".
> 
> But this rubbed me the wrong way:
> 
> I think that there is a further factor involved in this wishful 
thinking: intelligence as I defined is really a huge collection of 
intelligent behaviors leading many researchers to become overwhelmed 
and turn to hoping that an "emergent intelligence" will
spring like 
a phoenix from their work.  This is often combined with what I 
term "more-thinking": the hope that more speed, more
connections, 
more rules, more memory, etc., will cause disappointing results to 
transform into success.  This can be seen in followers of:  genetic 
algorithm (GA), artificial neural net (ANN), Bayesian reasoning, 
case based reasoning, etc.  The typical cycle observed by those in 
this field for the last couple of decades is: first a great deal of 
excitement surrounding initial experiments, then grandiose 
projections of further success, subsequent lack of further progress, 
and eventual lapsing into the belief that more resources will lead 
to success.And this:The current GA work largely ignores the 
complexity
>  required of the environment and fitness test for a meaningful 
application of the method (of which there has not been one to 
date).  These constraints dictate the possible outcomes of any GA 
process, which is merely shifting the difficult work from designing 
the processing algorithms to designing the environment and fitness 
algorithms.  Natural evolutionary process occurs in our complete 
environment.  Similar results are not likely unless a similar 
environment is modeled.  This is truly wishful thinking.Obviously I 
think he's wrong, and I'd guess many here do as well, so I'm 
interested in what you guys think about what he says.
> 

Hi Derek, I will try to respond to this author's "controversial" 
article.  I read the whole thing so I will write in general about 
everything he said, rather than just responding to the above quotes.

The author is trying to be controversial, to raise some objections, 
shake the boat a little.  But the article just sounds like the same 
old thing to me.  In fact, it sounds remarkably similar to the 
people the author is criticizing- those who are supposedly set in 
their close-minded ways.  After all, the author is essentially 
advocating a multi-pronged, modular approach, in which lots 
of "tools" are used together to produce the final product.  

The funny thing is, that is the same old-fashioned way of thinking 
that has long been motivating AI researchers:  this idea that some 
hodge-podge "toolbox" will be cobbled together out of 500 different 
and totally incompatible algorithms and data structures.  And then 
suddenly we'll have a brain.  What's new here?  The author claims 
that some people tend to specialize too much.  Fair enough, but we 
all know that the "visionaries," like the author, ultimately believe 
all these specialized notions might be pieced together eventually.

But no one has the faintest idea how this might happen.  So saying 
that it *should* happen hardly adds any value to the equation.

Here is an alternative plan: Creating a brain is an instance of the 
general class of problems of efficiently creating extremely complex 
structures (i.e. over 1 trillion parts; the brain has 100 trillion 
connections).  Efficiency is the key because if you spent even just 
1 second considering each of those trillion pieces, you'd spend 
about 31,000 years to put the solution together.  So, let them try, 
piece by piece.  In the meantime, let's find the fundamental 
principles behind generating complexity.  For example: it is easier 
to search first in a small space and then expand the space than it 
is to search starting directly in a larger space.  And, if a massive 
complex structure includes parts that are reused, then those reused 
parts should only be encoded *once* in the description of the 
solution.  There are probably a lot of other principles.  But you 
get my point: Let's find all the principles that allow us to both 
search and represent extreme complexity, and then apply those 
principles en masse to our massive problem, thus shaving off 
thousands of years of human effort or computation. 

It probably won't be enough- we'll probably then have to actually 
engineer some of the products of our principles to enhance and 
expand them further at certain points- a field which doesn't even 
exist yet.  

But the funny thing is, you may notice, I never mentioned NN's or 
GA's, but if you like my plan, you can't help but think, hmm NN's 
and GA's sound like what I'm talking about.  Now the question is, 
whose plan is actually new?
